description: Decoherence is the umbrella term for the loss of quantum coherence due to interaction with the environment. It encompasses two fundamental processes: energy relaxation (T1, amplitude damping) and phase randomization (T2, dephasing). Together, these processes cause quantum states to evolve toward classical mixtures.

The relationship between these timescales is given by 1/T2 = 1/(2T1) + 1/T2*, where T2* represents pure dephasing (phase loss without energy exchange). This means T2 ≤ 2T1 always holds — you cannot maintain phase coherence longer than twice the energy relaxation time.

In the Bloch sphere picture, decoherence causes states to spiral inward toward the thermal equilibrium point. T1 processes pull states toward |0⟩ (north pole at zero temperature), while T2 processes shrink the equatorial components. The combined effect is decay toward a point on the z-axis determined by the thermal population.

properties.Parameters: T1 = energy relaxation time, T2 = total dephasing time, T2* = pure dephasing time
properties.Thermal equilibrium: At T=0, decays to |0⟩; at finite T, decays to thermal mixture
properties.Timescales: Typical values: T1 ~ 100μs, T2 ~ 50-150μs for superconducting qubits

physical_examples: Superconducting qubits: T1 from dielectric loss, T2 from flux noise and charge noise
Trapped ions: T1 from spontaneous emission (very long), T2 from magnetic field fluctuations
Spin qubits: T1 from spin-lattice relaxation, T2 from nuclear spin bath
NV centers: T1 from phonon interactions, T2 from 13C nuclear spins
qem_considerations: Dynamical decoupling primarily targets T2 (dephasing) and is less effective for T1
Echo sequences can extend effective T2 toward the 2T1 limit by refocusing pure dephasing
ZNE and PEC can mitigate both T1 and T2 effects given sufficient noise characterization
Short circuits (depth << T1, T2) minimize decoherence exposure
Error mitigation overhead must be weighed against decoherence during extended execution
